title: Uganda: Enforce Axle Load to Save Our Roads
text:
Uganda: Ntagali Warns 2016 Poll Aspirants Against Consulting Witch Doctors 
Uganda National Roads Authority and Uganda Revenue Authority should be commended for at last taking the initiative to address this problem. Roads are very expensive to construct, with a single kilometre of tarmac alone costing more than Shs 1bn. 
Such an expensive road once made should be guarded jealously so that it can last its planned lifespan. 
However, the weigh bridges through which Unra enforces axle load controls had been turned into centres of extortion with errant truck drivers colluding with officials manning them to let overloaded trucks through freely or after paying a pittance in fines. 
Indeed, a Unra official was quoted as saying that the amount of money collected in fines at one of the weigh bridges over the one week this operation has been on is equivalent to what the roads body used to collect from the same throughout the year. 
With up to 90 per cent of all goods destined for Uganda from all over the world moving by road, our roads are in real danger of fast depreciation if overloading is not checked. 
As the country awaits the standard gauge railway (SGR) in a couple of years to relieve the roads of some of this burden, a serious effort must be made to use our costly road network sparingly. 
Truck drivers and truck owners might feel inconvenienced but it is in their long-term interest too to maintain a good road network. Uganda
